citations.narrative:
On two separate occasions, one in March 2024 and the other in November 2024, the facility lost two chickens due to
predation. The facility found the dead birds partly eaten inside the enclosure in March and outside near the enclosure in
November. The enclosures were not constructed in a manner to prevent predator entrance and thus did not safely contain
the animals. Enclosures must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.

The contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was dated in June 2022, more than 3 years ago. The
plan must be reviewed at least annually to ensure that it continues to adequately address the regulatory requirements and
the facility must maintain documentation of those annual reviews. Correct by ensuring the facility's contingency plan is
reviewed annually and maintaining documentation of the annual reviews.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 18, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On two separate occasions, one in March 2024 and the other in November 2024, the facility lost two chickens due to 
predation. The facility found the dead birds partly eaten inside the enclosure in March and outside near the enclosure in 
November. The enclosures were not constructed in a manner to prevent predator entrance and thus did not safely contain 
the animals. Enclosures must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was dated in June 2022, more than 3 years ago. The 
plan must be reviewed at least annually to ensure that it continues to adequately address the regulatory requirements and 
the facility must maintain documentation of those annual reviews. Correct by ensuring the facility's contingency plan is 
reviewed annually and maintaining documentation of the annual reviews. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 18, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
